results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: How to watch meteor showers
results.abstract: 2023 should be a good year for meteor lovers.

results.title: A Toxic Stew on Cape Cod: Human Waste and Warming Water
results.abstract: Climate change is contributing to electric-green algae blooms. Massachusetts wants a cleanup of the antiquated septic systems feeding the mess, but it could cost billions.
results.byline: By Christopher Flavelle and Sophie Park

multimedia.caption: Ashley Fisher, director of the Mashpee Department of Natural Resources in Massachusetts, took samples from the bed of the Mashpee River earlier this month.
Ashley Fisher, director of the Mashpee Department of Natural Resources in Massachusetts, took samples from the bed of the Mashpee River earlier this month.
Ashley Fisher, director of the Mashpee Department of Natural Resources in Massachusetts, took samples from the bed of the Mashpee River earlier this month.

results.title: Ahead of Major Court Case, E.P.A. Revises Clean-Water Protections
results.abstract: A new rule revives an older set of protections for rivers, marshes and waterways, setting aside changes in the Obama and Trump administrations that led to years of legal wrangling.

multimedia.caption: The E.P.A. is taking the action before a Supreme Court decision that could limit the agency’s authority to act in the future.

results.title: The U.S. Will Need Thousands of Wind Farms. Will Small Towns Go Along?
results.abstract: In the fight against climate change, national goals are facing local resistance. One county scheduled 19 nights of meetings to debate one wind farm.

multimedia.copyright: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times

results.title: Justice Dept. Sues AmerisourceBergen Over Role in Opioid Crisis
results.abstract: Investigators said the pharmaceutical manufacturer, one of the nation’s largest, had knowingly distributed opioids that were later resold illegally.
results.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Livia Albeck-Ripka

multimedia.caption: AmerisourceBergen is accused of hundreds of thousands of potential violations of the Controlled Substances Act.
AmerisourceBergen is accused of hundreds of thousands of potential violations of the Controlled Substances Act.

results.title: How Bad Is China’s Covid Outbreak? It’s a Scientific Guessing Game.
results.abstract: In the absence of credible information from the Chinese government, researchers around the world are looking for any clues to determine the size and severity of the surge.
results.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Benjamin Mueller

results.title: ‘Wildcat’ Review: Rescue and Rewild
results.abstract: This documentary follows a couple’s efforts to reintroduce an ocelot, headed to a zoo or worse, into its home in the Peruvian Amazon.

multimedia.caption: Khan, the ocelot rescued by a young American ecologist, Samantha Zwicker, and her British partner, Harry Turner.
Khan, the ocelot rescued by a young American ecologist, Samantha Zwicker, and her British partner, Harry Turner.

results.title: U.S. to Require Negative Covid Tests for Travelers Coming From China
results.abstract: Amid concerns about a coronavirus surge in Beijing, the Biden administration announced the change in policy for those entering the United States from China, including Hong Kong and Macau.
results.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: A medical worker performing a Covid test in Danzhai, China.
A medical worker performing a Covid test in Danzhai, China.
A medical worker performing a Covid test in Danzhai, China.

results.title: A ‘Once in a Generation’ Storm. What’s the Role of Climate Change?
results.abstract: The deadly freeze that swept the United States was extraordinary, but while scientists know that global warming can intensify extreme weather, the effects on winter storms are tricky to untangle.

multimedia.caption: An ice-covered home near Lake Erie in Hamburg, N.Y.
An ice-covered home near Lake Erie in Hamburg, N.Y.
An ice-covered home near Lake Erie in Hamburg, N.Y.

results.title: As Covid-19 Continues to Spread, So Does Misinformation About It
results.abstract: Doctors are exasperated by the persistence of false and misleading claims about the virus.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: The constant barrage of bad information about Covid-19 has made it increasingly difficult for accurate advice to break through, misinformation researchers say.
The constant barrage of bad information about Covid-19 has made it increasingly difficult for accurate advice to break through, misinformation researchers say.

results.title: Parents Often Bring Children to Psychiatric E.R.s to Subdue Them, Study Finds
results.abstract: Many parents bring children to emergency rooms to manage aggressive behaviors. But the visits offer little long-term benefit, doctors said.

multimedia.caption: Patients who required medications to subdue them were 22 percent more likely to revisit an emergency room than patients who did not, the study found.
multimedia.copyright: Tim Gruber for The New York Times

results.title: Epidemics That Weren’t: How Countries Shut Down Recent Outbreaks
results.abstract: Some of the most fragile health systems in the world can teach us ways to respond to public health threats early and effectively.

multimedia.caption: Volunteers received training on how to conduct safe and dignified burials for Ebola victims in Mubende, Uganda, in October.
Volunteers received training on how to conduct safe and dignified burials for Ebola victims in Mubende, Uganda, in October.

results.title: China to Drop Covid Quarantine for Incoming Travelers
results.abstract: From Jan. 8, visitors will be required to show only a negative P.C.R. test taken within 48 hours. The restrictions had cut the country off from the rest of the world for nearly three years.

multimedia.caption: The Beijing Daxing International Airport on Monday. In November, the number of international flights to China was 6 percent of what it was in 2019, according to the flight tracker VariFlight.
The Beijing Daxing International Airport on Monday. In November, the number of international flights to China was 6 percent of what it was in 2019, according to the flight tracker VariFlight.

results.title: The I.C.U. Nurse: A Symbol of Endurance
results.abstract: Caring for seriously ill patients needing round-the-clock attention during the pandemic has added layers of commitment.
results.byline: By Isadora Kosofsky and Andrew Jacobs
org_facet: Providence Saint John's Health Center (Santa Monica, Calif)

results.title: Hope, Regret, Uncertainty: 7 Women on Freezing Their Eggs
results.abstract: Ten years have passed since the procedure’s “experimental” label was lifted. The Times heard from hundreds of patients about their experiences.

results.title: This Party Season, You Don’t Have to R.S.V.P., Just Test
results.abstract: As rising Covid rates collide with a return to holiday festivities, hosts are coming up with inventive compromises.
results.byline: By Roni Caryn Rabin and Holly Secon

multimedia.caption: A holiday party in Manhattan last year moved outside to reduce Covid risk. Party planners are contemplating rapid tests, outdoor settings and reduced guest lists to curb the spread of Covid.

results.title: Day 23: On Christmas Day, No Rest for the Weary. (Or the Guy Who Feeds the Penguins.)
results.abstract: For a biologist in San Francisco, Dec. 25 will bring not presents and mistletoe, but beak trims and fish guts.

multimedia.caption: San Francisco biologist Sparks Perkins works on Christmas to tend to the needs of the resident penguins at the California Academy of Sciences’s Steinhart Aquarium. He holds an African penguin chick. New swimming feathers, stiffer and sleek, are replacing the chick’s fuzzy baby down.
multimedia.copyright: LeeAndra Cianci, Photo by Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times

results.abstract: Dozens of doctors said the nonprofit hospital pressured them to give preferential treatment to donors, trustees and their families.

results.title: ‘Tripledemic’ Rages On: Fever-Filled Weeks Lie Ahead
results.abstract: R.S.V. has probably peaked, but flu is still surging and Covid-19 cases are rising. Scientists are hopeful next winter will be better.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Experts say several hard, fever-filled weeks still lie ahead. “A lot of sniffly kids,” one epidemiologist said.
Experts say several hard, fever-filled weeks still lie ahead. “A lot of sniffly kids,” one epidemiologist said.

results.title: What Is the Polar Vortex? And Other Cold-Weather Climate Questions
results.abstract: As much of the United States plunges into a deep freeze, scientists continue to debate how rapid Arctic warming is playing a role.

results.title: A Science Reporter Asks: ‘Where Are the Aliens?’
results.abstract: Kenneth Chang, a Times science reporter, covers a broad range of topics, including nuclear fusion and the conditions favorable to life outside our solar system.

multimedia.caption: The target bay of the National Ignition Facility at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, Calif. Scientists in the lab reached a milestone last week when a nuclear fusion reaction generated more energy than was required to start it.

results.title: As Covid Deaths Climb, Even Seniors Skip the Latest Booster
results.abstract: Nearly all Americans over 65 got their initial Covid vaccines. But that immunity is waning, and this time, the government is offering far less support for new shots.
org_facet: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

multimedia.caption: Debbie Toth, the chief executive of the nonprofit Choice in Aging in Pleasant Hill, Calif., with participants Tsilya Tankover, left, and Alexandr Makedonsky.

results.title: Congress Offers $1 Billion for Climate Aid, Falling Short of Biden’s Pledge
results.abstract: Activists called the funding to help developing countries cope with the impacts of climate change “hugely disappointing.”
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: The $1 billion falls far short of the billions President Biden had pledged to international climate change spending.
The $1 billion falls far short of the billions President Biden had pledged to international climate change spending.
The $1 billion falls far short of the billions President Biden had pledged to international climate change spending.

results.title: E.P.A. Tightens Rules on Pollution From Vans, Buses and Trucks
results.abstract: For the first time in decades, the agency has restricted nitrogen dioxide emissions from heavy vehicles.

multimedia.caption: The rule will require heavy-duty trucks to reduce emissions of nitrogen dioxide 48 percent by 2045.
The rule will require heavy-duty trucks to reduce emissions of nitrogen dioxide 48 percent by 2045.
The rule will require heavy-duty trucks to reduce emissions of nitrogen dioxide 48 percent by 2045.
